entry.title: Did real-life events inspire the myth of Atlantis?
entry.summary:
An illustration by Sir Gerald Hargreaves shows a utopian scene on a cove of the mythical land of Atlantis. Many scholars think Plato invented the story of Atlantis as a way to present his philosophical theories.

The lost city of Atlantis likely didnâ€™t exist, but Platoâ€™s fascinating island nation continues to spark questions. Hereâ€™s what to know. Atlantis is an island nation mentioned in two of the Greek philosopher Platoâ€™s most famous dialogues, Timaeus and Critias. In them, he describes the ancient civilization as peaceful and vastly wealthy, protected by the sea god Poseidon. But although itâ€™s one of his most famous stories, itâ€™s almost certainly false. So why is this stâ€¦

entry.title: We finally know where potatoes come fromâ€”and the answer is weird
entry.summary:
Researchers are hoping to use the discovery of the potato's lineage to create healthier potato plants. New research traces the genetic ancestry of the popular root vegetable to a brief plant romance millions of years ago.
Tomato to potato? To-mah-to to po-tah-to? Turns out, we can thank the tomato for our beloved potato.
A new study, published in Cell, has traced the genetic origins of our modern potatoes. The results show that a cross-breeding event eight to nine million years ago between an ancient tomato relative and another ancient plant gave rise to the first potato. That plant romance resulted in a gene combination that grew a thick, starchy tuberâ€”the birth of the iconic spud we all know and love.
(How the potato went from banned to beloved.)
More than just aâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 168 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from April 14 to April 20, 2025. A total of 9,397 panelists responded out of 10,559 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Online Scams and Attacks in America Today
entry.summary: 73% of U.S. adults have experienced some kind of online scam or attack, and these are common across age groups. Most get scam calls, texts and emails at least weekly. The post Online Scams and Attacks in America Today appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: In early August, Heads of State, ministers, investors and grassroots leaders will gather in Awaza on Turkmenistanâ€™s Caspian coast for once-in-a-decade UN conference aiming to rewire the global system in support of 32 landlocked developing countries whose economies are often â€œlocked outâ€ of opportunity due to their lack of access to the sea.

entry.summary: As Myanmar reels from deadly floods, renewed fighting and widespread displacement, the United Nations warned on Thursday that urgent humanitarian needs are going unmet due to escalating violence and blocked access.

entry.summary: Famine conditions are tightening their grip on the Gaza Strip, as the latest UN humanitarian update warns of soaring malnutrition-related deaths, relentless civilian attacks, and mounting obstacles to aid access amid deepening crisis.

entry.summary: What began as protests against fuel price hikes in Angola have escalated into deadly unrest across the country, with at least 22 people killed and more than 1,000 detained, prompting calls from the UN for restraint and urgent investigations into possible rights violations by security forces.

entry.title: Scientists found cut marks on a 850,000-year-old human neck bone. Was it ... cannibalism?
entry.summary: Homo antecessor teeth found at the Gran Dolina site, Atapuerca. Bones found here have provided evidence of cannibalism among these ancient hominins. The vertebra from Spain's Gran Dolina cave may show that an ancient human relative cannibalized its own kind, though not all scientists agree. A toddlerâ€™s neck bone discovered with clear cut-marks dating to about 850,000 years ago may be evidence that an ancient hominin species, Homo antecessor, cannibalized a child, according to archaeologists in Spain. The researchers say the finding, announced July 24, is further indication of Paleolithic cannibalism at Gran Dolina cave in Spain's Sierra de Atapuerca, where signs of ancient humans butchering one another have been found for decades.Â  "This is direct evidence thatâ€¦

entry.title: This Canadian highway is perfect for an idyllic road trip
entry.summary: The Elk River in Fernie is well-regarded among fly fishers for trout fishing. The British Columbia portion of Highway 3, also known as Crowsnest Highway, offers one hidden gem after anotherâ€”from small town charm to hiking, camping, and canoeing. In a province as big and beautiful as British Columbia, it can be hard to find a drive that stands out from the rest. However, Highway 3, better known as the Crowsnest Highway, takes drivers through lush forests, semi-arid grasslands, high mountain peaks, and valleys. This route runs from Hope, British Columbia, all the way to the edge of the province and beyond into Alberta. The highwayâ€™s name comes from Crowsnest Pass, although the origin is up for some debate. The British Columbia portion is around 520 miles long (aroundâ€¦

entry.title: Just how bad was Bad King John?
entry.summary:
John I, known as John Lackland, has been depicted as the most villainous king in the history of England. In accounts of his reign, the monastic chroniclers emphasize Johnâ€™s score-settling, even sadistic, temper and his blatant contempt for the church. Any positive qualities he may have had as a king have been obscured.
The figure of King John also contrasts sharply with that of his brother Richard the Lionheart, the quintessential English hero. Richard has gone down in history as one of the most glorious kings of England, even though he spent only six months of his reign in the country. John, on the other hand, is often labeled as Bad King John, and no subsequent English king would bear his name. Johnâ€™s reputation for cruelty was cemented by Sir Walter Scottâ€™s historical novel Ivanhoeâ€¦

entry.title: 6 science-backed strategies to improve your memory
entry.summary:
If you find yourself forgetting things, here are a few science-backed ways to remember things better. Forget your keys again? Studying for a test? The best method for improving your memory depends on what youâ€™re trying to remember.
Forgetting is normal, but it can make life difficult. You might forget someoneâ€™s name seconds after you meet them, blank on where youâ€™ve put your keys, or miss an important birthday.Â Â
Memories are fallible for a reason. Without a mechanism for forgetting, you would be unable to filter out unnecessary information when youâ€™re trying to remember something. â€œYou don't want to fill your brain with clutter,â€ says Charan Ranganath, a neuroscientist at the University of California, Davis.Â
To improve your memory, however, most doctors will recommend aâ€¦

entry.title: 8 war memorial sites everybody should visit on a trip to Vietnam
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This year marks half a century since the end of the Vietnam War, or the American War, as itâ€™s known in Vietnam. The conflict dragged on for almost 20 years, from 1955 to 1975, with the US army supporting the anti-communist South Vietnam against pro-communist North Vietnam, which was in turn supported by international communist allies. It was a period of civil war that had a profound impact on Vietnam. Today, the people of this fast-growing Southeast Asian country have taken great strides to put the war behind them, but they honour Vietnamâ€™s past with a number of monuments and museums nationwide. Many of these sites have become incredibly popular with history buffs â€” and visiting them can be a profound, moving and eye-opâ€¦

entry.title: Scientists reconstruct the tattoos of a 2,000-year-old ice mummy
entry.summary:
3D model of the tattooed ice mummy who belonged to the nomadic group known as the Pazyryk. The top images was created from visible spectrum photographs and the bottom from near infrared photography. New imaging technology has allowed scientists to decipher the tattoos of an Iron Age mummyâ€”and study them like never before.
From tribal symbols to the name of an ex, people have long adorned their skin with ink. Countless cultures have developed and practiced the art of tattooing for at least 5,000 years. Among the most famous examples are Ã–tzi the Iceman, found frozen in the Alps with 61 tattoos, and the Chinchorro mummy of ancient Chile, marked with black, mustache-like dots thought to be tattoos beneath his nose.
Despite their ubiquity, ancient tattoos are difficult to study. Sâ€¦

entry.title: UK gin distilleries that are worth the journey
entry.summary:
More than 800 distilleries operate across the UK, each offering signature botanicals and all manner of inventive tasting experiences. From coastal labs in Cornwall to country farms in Northumberland, the UKâ€™s gin scene has an ever-expanding number of unique distilleries offering exciting tasting experiences. Here are eight of the country's best.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Britain has a deep-rooted relationship with gin. This long and sometimes complicated love affair has evolved from moments of codependency â€” notably during the 18th-century â€˜gin crazeâ€™, when many poorer Londoners were hooked on often home-distilled hooch â€” to the period of relative abstinence that followed with the Gin Act of 1751 restricting who could sell the stuff. â€¦

entry.title: What causes earthquakes?
entry.summary:
Earthquakes, also called temblors, can be so tremendously destructive that itâ€™s hard to imagine they occur by the thousands every day around the world, usually in the form of small tremors. Most are so small that people canâ€™t feel them.
But even smaller quakes can cause a stir. On January 27, 2025, an earthquake near York Harbor, Maine, with a preliminary magnitude of 3.8 rattled parts of New England as far south as Boston and Rhode Island around 10:22 am EST.
In the United States, East Coast earthquakes happen less frequently than those on the West Coast, but they can be felt over a broader area. Earthquakes can also trigger tsunamis that can impact shores thousands of miles away. The 8.8-magnitude earthquake that rumbled off Russiaâ€™s Kamchatka Peninsula on July 29, 2025 caused â€¦

entry.title: Tsunamis
entry.summary:
In 2011, more than 1,500 people died in Rikuzentakata, one of several towns in Japan impacted by a devastating tsunami. Tsunamis are most often caused by underwater earthquakes. Climate change is making them worse.
One of the strongest earthquakes ever recorded struck Russiaâ€™s Far East this week, issuing tsunami alerts across much of the Pacific. The 8.8 magnitude earthquake set off warnings in Hawaii, North and Central America, Japan, and the Pacific islands.
A tsunami is a series of ocean waves that sends surges of water, sometimes reaching heights of over 100 feet (30.5 meters), onto land. These walls of water can cause widespread destruction and death when they crash ashore.
Japan has been impacted by strong earthquakes in the past, with a 9.1 magnitude quake hittingâ€¦

entry.title: How the Mandela effect tricks your brain with false memories
entry.summary:
Cape Town street art depicts former South African President Nelson Mandela. A phenomenon known as the Mandela effect originates from the false memory of Nelson Mandela passing away during his imprisonment in the 1980s. Darth Vader never said, â€œLuke I am your father.â€ So why do we all think he did? Hereâ€™s the science behind this strange phenomenonâ€”and how AI is poised to send it into overdrive.
Darth Vader never actually said â€œLuke I am your father.â€ Your favorite childrenâ€™s book series was theÂ Berenstain Bears, not theÂ Berenstein Bears. And the cow onÂ Laughing CowÂ cheese never actually had a nose ring.
These are some of the most famous examples of a phenomenon known as the Mandela effect â€”anÂ experience where the public collectively misremembers an image, event, or phrase.Â â€¦

entry.title: Who was the first king of England?
entry.summary:
Scholarly consensus positions Aethelstan as the first true king of England.Â But what makes a king? Is it authority over people? Over land? Is it some combination of the two?Â
These are some of the key questions in assessing when and why any monarchy develops. At the same time, these same questions often serve to complicate the identification of the first king of any realm. We need not look further than England to understand why.Â
Aethelstan was crowned King of the Anglo-Saxons in 925 A.D.Â However, understanding the other contenders for that titleâ€”and the history of the disparate kingdoms that became Englandâ€”adds layers of complexity to answering the deceptively simple question: who was the first king of England?Â
To really begin to locate the first king of England, one musâ€¦

entry.title: Planning the next family trip? Look to Galveston
entry.summary:
Under-the-radar Galveston has a lot to offer families, from engaging animal encounters to fascinating history brought to life. A 1900s boomtown with cosmopolitan flair, this coastal destination is now well-suited for families looking to combine warm-weather escapes with historic attractions and educational experiences.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Stretched along the coast of the Gulf of Mexico in Texas, Galveston is where maritime history, ornate Victorian mansions and a decidedly Floridian beach-town vibe seamlessly blend. A popular choice among late-19th century holidaying elites and investors looking for new prospects, this barrier island became the richest city in the state, packing Southern charm and wild decadence into its gilded maâ€¦

entry.title: Extreme heat may age you as much as smoking or heavy drinking
entry.summary:
Frequent exposure to extreme heat may age the body nearly as much as smoking, new research showsâ€”triggering internal stress that wears down organs and alters genes. Recent studies show that chronic heat exposure accelerates biological aging, but experts say there are ways to stay protected.
If you live in cities like Phoenix, Houston, or Miami, where temperatures routinely climb above 90 degrees, youâ€™re not just sweating through your clothes. You may also be aging faster than people in cooler climates. Thatâ€™s the takeaway fromÂ aÂ growingÂ body ofÂ research suggesting that long-term exposure to high heat can accelerate biological aging at the cellular level, sometimes in ways comparable to smoking or heavy drinking.
â€œOur study found that people living in areas of extreme heat had â€¦

entry.title: With Gaza smouldering, ministers renew push for two-State solution at UN
entry.summary: With Gaza in ruins and the two-State solution in jeopardy, ministers convened at the United Nations this week to jumpstart political momentum toward ending the Israeli-Palestinian conflict â€“ a crisis Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres warned is â€œat a breaking point.â€

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Violence in Somalia, cholera in Haiti, tax support for sustainable development
entry.summary: Ongoing violence has displaced more than 100,000 people in two regions of Somalia in the past two months, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan gripped by deadly crisis as hunger, disease and heat intensify
entry.summary: The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) raised the alarm on Wednesday over the rising toll of hunger, disease and displacement in various conflict-ridden parts of Sudan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza children starving despite Israeli â€˜tactical pausesâ€™, UN says
entry.summary: Despite daily â€œtactical pausesâ€ declared by Israeli forces, humanitarian conditions in Gaza remain catastrophic, with children starving, aid workers overwhelmed, and fuel and water supplies critically low, UN humanitarians reported on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Haitians in â€˜despairâ€™ following abrupt suspension of US humanitarian support
entry.summary: People in Haiti have expressed â€œdespairâ€ following the â€œabrupt suspensionâ€ of a wide range of humanitarian services, according to the UNÂ aid coordinationÂ office,Â OCHA, in the Caribbean country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tsunami alert highlights worth of global early warning system
entry.summary: Early warning systems kicked in overnight across Pacific coastal communities after a massive earthquake in eastern Russia triggered a sea surge that reached the Japanese coastline around 1,000 kilometres (620 miles) away within about an hour, disaster relief experts said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Cholera outbreak in West and Central Africa poses crisis for children
entry.summary: Some 80,000 children are estimated to be at high risk of cholera in West and Central Africa as the rainy season begins across the region, the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: LIVE COVERAGE: Day 3 of high-level conference on two-State solution for Israel and Palestine
entry.summary: Welcome to our live coverage of the third day of high-level international conference at UN Headquarters, aimed at advancing practical steps toward achieving a two-State solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict. Mandated by the General Assembly meeting features plenaries, working groups and interventions from senior UN officials and Member States. UN News app users can follow here.

entry.title: Velociraptorâ€™s new cousin is a raptor unlike any seen before
entry.summary: The newly named raptor Shri rapax was smuggled by poachers, rescued from the black market, and then, sometime following a CT-scan in 2016, its skull went missing. Shri rapax had bigger claws and potentially a stronger bite than its Hollywood relative. But paleontologists still donâ€™t know the whereabouts of its head, which went missing. Sometime before 2010, in the red sands of Mongoliaâ€™s Gobi Desert brimming with fossils, poachers excavated and stole the exquisite skeleton of a carnivorous dinosaur. They smuggled the fossil out of the country and onto the black market. It passed through private collections in Japan and England and was eventually acquired by the French fossil company Eldonia. In 2016, one of the fossilâ€™s owners had the dinosaurâ€™s skull and four vertebraeâ€¦

entry.title: 7 unusual outdoor events, from the offbeat to the awe-inspiring
entry.summary:
Celebrate Trails Day, hosted by The Great American Rail-Trail, encourages people to get outside and be active. Pond skimming, sprinting in heelsâ€”these annual adventures range from death-defying to mundane.
Weâ€™ve been hearing a lot in recent years about how awe is good for our mental and physical health. Finding awe in adventure can be as simple as watching others do something incredible or trying it ourselves. Research suggests a viral, contagious component to wondrous encounters, enhanced when we share them with othersâ€”not on social media, but as an actual experience.
Awe can be triggered by art, nature, people, or acts of mind-blowing skill or risk. Like from skiing down a snow-covered hill before skimming across a pond of cold water, or from watching a group of people in a â€¦

entry.title: What lymphatic drainage massage actually does for your body
entry.summary:
Lymphatic drainage massages have become a popular treatment for those looking to slim their face, but experts say the real benefits of lymphatic treatments are often misunderstood. â€œLymphfluencersâ€ claim this type of massage can filter out toxins, help you lose weight, and boost your immune system. Hereâ€™s what science says.
From dry brushes to targeted massages, lymphatic drainage is prolific across social media. A single influencerâ€™s video can accumulate over a million views with promises that massage techniques will eliminate waste or boost weight loss.
But lymphatic medicine is nothing new: Hippocrates observed and described lymph nodes in the fourth century B.C. The first known use of the term â€œlymphaticsâ€ was in the 1600s in Denmark and Sweden, and medical scholars began â€¦

entry.title: How knitting may be rewiring your brain
entry.summary:
From knitting to woodwork, slow and steady hobbies may offer surprising brain benefits, including reduced stress and better long-term memory. â€œGrandma hobbiesâ€ like knitting are making a comeback among Gen Zâ€”but itâ€™s not just for nostalgia. Neuroscience shows these tactile pastimes may help preserve brain health as we age.
The rhythmic click of needles. The softness of yarn running over fingertips. The satisfying logic of knit, purl, repeat. Knittingâ€”and other so-called â€œgrandma hobbiesâ€â€”is making a comeback, especially among younger generations. According to Eventbrite data, Gen Zâ€™s interest in â€œgrannycoreâ€ gatherings, such as knitting circles and needlework workshops, has surged in recent months, driven in part by a search for relief from digital burnout.
But the benefits goâ€¦

entry.title: Whales are going eerily silent. Experts say itâ€™s a warning sign.
entry.summary:
A blue whale swims near the coast of Sri Lanka. Studies from California to New Zealand have shown that certain whale species, such as blue whales, stop singing when heat waves disrupt their food sources. A six-year study off Californiaâ€™s coast shows how marine heat waves and noise pollution are silencing the oceanâ€™s largest singers. Does saving the ocean start with hearing it?
Beneath the ocean's surface, a symphony ripples and rolls, ricochets and humsâ€”and whales pour their songs into the deep soundscape like streams of molten silver.
Deep within the noise, a 32-mile-long cable stretches out from the California coastline along the seafloor, tethered to the ground 3,000 feet below the surface. At its end is a two-inch-wide metal cylinder standing on three legs. This hydrophoneâ€¦

entry.title: Lured by hope, trapped by lies: Healing after being trafficked
entry.summary: The promise seemed simple: a job, a fresh start, a way out. Instead, Maria* stepped off a boat onto a picture-perfect Trinidadian beach with hope in her heart and into a nightmare that would shadow her for years. On theÂ World Day Against Trafficking in Persons, observed on 30 July, follow the journey of a woman who escaped.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Deputy UN chief urges bold action to transform food systems at global summit in Addis Ababa
entry.summary: United Nations Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed on Tuesday called on countries to double down on efforts to transform food systems, describing them as â€œone of the greatest solutionsâ€ to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Remembering Dr. David Nabarro, deadly shipwreck off Libya, verdict in peacekeeperâ€™s killing
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres has expressed sadness over the passing of Dr. David Nabarro, who played a leading role in the Organizationâ€™s efforts to respond to challenges such as hunger, Ebola and the COVID-19 pandemic.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN peacekeeping can work in a fractured world â€“ if there is political will
entry.summary: In an era marked by geopolitical fragmentation and rising global tensions, United Nations peace operations face unprecedented challenges â€“ but senior officials told the Security Council on Tuesday that with renewed political will and strategic adaptation, these missions remain indispensable tools for conflict resolution and protection of civilians worldwide.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Russian attack on Ukrainian prison kills 16: UN rights monitors
entry.summary: An attack on a prison in the south-eastern Zaporizhzhia region of Ukraine on Monday reportedly left 16 prisoners dead and almost 100 injured, violating international law, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) has said.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜By women, for womenâ€™: 15 years of the UN agency championing gender equality
entry.summary: Fariba, a young Afghan woman, had just begun a university degree in 2021 when the TalibanÂ returned to power and banned women and girls from secondary and higher education.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: LIVE COVERAGE: Day 2 of high-level conference on two-State solution for Israel and Palestine
entry.summary: Welcome to our continuing live coverage of the high-level international conference at UN Headquarters, aimed at advancing practical steps toward achieving a two-State solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict. Mandated by the General Assembly, the three-day meeting features plenaries, working groups and interventions from senior UN officials and Member States. UN News app users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: In Gaza, mounting evidence of famine and widespread starvation
entry.summary: â€œThe worst-case scenario of famine is currently playing out in Gaza,â€Â UN-backed food security experts said on Tuesday, in a call to action amid unrelenting conflict, mass displacement and the near-total collapse of essential services in the war-battered enclave.

entry.title: Who were the Moors?
entry.summary:
If the term â€œMoorâ€ seems familiar but confusing, thereâ€™s a reason. Though it can be found throughout literature, art, and history books, it does not actually describe a specific ethnicity or race.
Instead, the concept of Moors has been used to describe alternatively the reign of Muslims in Spain, Europeans of African descent, and others for centuries.
Derived from the Latin word â€œMaurus,â€ the term was originally used to describe Berbers and ethnic groups from the ancient Roman province of Mauretania in what is now North Africa.
Over time, it was increasingly applied to the Muslim population living in Europe. Beginning in the Renaissance, â€œMoorâ€ and â€œblackamoorâ€ were also used to describe any person with dark skin.
In A.D. 711, a group of North African Muslims led by tâ€¦

entry.title: Program Director
entry.summary: The Global Investigative Journalism Network (GIJN) is looking for a Program Director to plan, lead, develop, and implement cutting-edge programs to foster the practice of investigative journalism across the globe. This full-time position will be part of GIJNâ€™s management team, working to advance GIJNâ€™s mission of supporting and strengthening investigative journalism worldwide â€” with special [â€¦]

The role will report to and work closely with the Institute Director and be part of the senior management team. This is an exciting opportunity [â€¦]

This role will, for the first time, provide unified strategic oversight of all long-form documentary commissions, including world service [â€¦]

The department is responsible for commissioning a wide range of current affairs programmes, including Channel Four News, Dispatches, Unreported World, Untold, major current affairs documentaries, studio programmes and series. The dedicated Investigations Unit is [â€¦]

entry.title: Are orange cats really the goofiest? Genetics may have an answer.
entry.summary:
Orange cats are said to have goofy personalities. Is that really true? The best science on ginger feline behavior hints, yeah, there might be something special about them.
Hanging from lamps, catapulting off countertops, tackling the dog, biting your legs unexpectedlyâ€”there are many wacky behaviors associated with orange cats, often captured on TikTok, whose owners swear are extra derpy, slapdash, and yet also friendly to a fault.
But scientifically speaking, are orange cats actually any different than cats of other colors?
For starters, orange cats are not a breed, like British shorthair or Siamese. Cats of many breeds, from Maine coons and munchkins to American bobtails and Siberians, can have orange colorations. Which perhaps makes it all the weirder that orange cat aâ€¦

entry.title: 7 bullet train journeys across China
entry.summary:
China's high-speed bullet trains are a great way to explore different areas of the country. With the worldâ€™s longest high-speed rail network and a new record-breaking bullet train, China is reshaping how travelers explore this vast nation.
On a clear Beijing morning, I settle into my seat on board the G87 bullet train. Bound for Chengdu, weâ€™ll make the nearly 1,200-mile journeyâ€”about the distance from New York City to Kansas Cityâ€”in just 7.5 hours. Through the window, buildings blur as we quietly pick up speed and soon weâ€™re sailing across the Yellow River, past Xiâ€™anâ€™s ancient walls, and into the mountains of Sichuan.
China is blazing a new future with its rail network, which includes more than 28,500 miles of high-speed tracks (for comparison, Europeâ€™s is around 7,450 miles)â€¦

entry.title: Who was Nostradamusâ€”and why do his prophecies rile us up?
entry.summary:
Whatâ€™s in the futureâ€¦and how does the world end?Â Theyâ€™re tempting questionsâ€”and one that, centuries ago, doctor and self-styled prophet Nostradamus always claimed to answer. His famed predictions range from confusing to creepy, and his acolytes believe his 16th-century predictions still ring true today. HisÂ supposed 2025 prophecies include long wars, plague, and a fireball that may destroy Earth.
In fact, Nostradamus is so well known for his predictions that a 1672Â referenceÂ to him is among the first documented uses of the word â€œprognosticationâ€ in the English language.Â
But the man some think of as a prophet was no divine being. He was a real-life French physician, apothecary, and author whose bold predictions earned him a name in the tumult of Renaissance Europe. Hereâ€™s what toâ€¦

entry.title: Female invasive joro spiders may dabble in cannibalism
entry.summary: Invasive joro spiders have been building their enormous, golden webs across the eastern United States since 2014. Sometimes the webs stand alone, but other times 10 or 15 females dwell in a mosaic of interconnected webs stretching all the way up a treeâ€”an arachnid apartment complex of sorts. New research finds that these stereotypically tolerant spiders can engage in unneighborly behavior, attacking and even cannibalizing each other. undefinedTo study female joro spider fighting in the field, researchers placed pairs on the same web. Just one pair fought. Joro spiders are native to east Asia. Females look like a yellow and black grape with toothpicks sticking out of itâ€”big enough to fill the palm of a hand, says Andy Davis, an ecologist at the University of Georgia in Athens. â€œFoâ€¦

entry.title: This Parisian chef is fighting for feminism from the kitchen
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Manon Fleury approaches being a chef the same way she does fencing. â€œGastronomy is often presented as a job in which you compete against others â€” but in reality, itâ€™s not at all,â€ says Fleury, who, prior to opening her Paris restaurant Datil, was a member of the French fencing team. Demanding schedules, adrenaline and the ultimate satisfaction that comes with success can be found in both disciplines. But itâ€™s teamwork thatâ€™s important above all else. â€œWhat I advocate for at Datil is helping one another, kindness and respect â€” values that can also be found in sports â€”Â while going above and beyond, a requirement in upscale gastronomy.â€
Building a healthy work environment was one of the main concerns when Datil openedâ€¦

entry.title: 8 of the most beautiful train stations in the U.S.
How Charles Lindbergh almost convinced Europe to cave to Hitler
entry.summary:
Charles Lindbergh standing in front of his plane, the Spirit of St. Louis, which he used on his transatlantic flight. The aviator was so impressed by German propaganda that he grossly overestimated Hitlerâ€™s airpower.
I have to declare a personal stake that shapes my opinion as I write this story. It has its origins in 1940, 85 years ago this month. I was seven years old, living near London. I watched the choreography of a great battle underway, etched in vapor trails high above in the crisp blue sky of summer, the combat that became known as the Battle of Britain. I wasnâ€™t scared. I watched with the detached excitement of a child unaware of how perilous those days were for us. That understanding would come later, from my work as a journalist, spending years discovering how closely â€¦

entry.title: World News in Brief: Cambodia-Thailand ceasefire, bloody weekend in Ukraine, stop hepatitis deaths
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres has welcomed the ceasefire agreement between Cambodia and Thailand following days of deadly fighting over their mutual border.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: UN sounds the alarm as health and food crises worsen across the country
entry.summary: The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) is alarmed by escalating health and food crises across Sudan, notably as cholera cases continue to rise in the locality of Tawila, North Darfur state.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Slight decrease in global hunger as inequalities widen, UN report reveals
entry.summary: An interagency group from the UN released the flagshipÂ 2025 State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World (SOFI) report on Monday, estimating a global, yet uneven, decline in hunger since 2022.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: Fragile ceasefire in Sweida â€˜largely holdingâ€™ amid volatility
entry.summary: A fragile de-escalation in Syriaâ€™s Sweida region is â€œlargely holdingâ€ after weeks of violence displaced 175,000 people, killed hundreds and devastated critical infrastructure â€“ exposing deep fissures in the countryâ€™s political transition.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN condemns deadly attack on worshippers in DR Congo
entry.summary: The UN peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, MONUSCO, strongly condemned an attack by the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) on civilians during the night of 26 to 27 July.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres: â€˜Breaking pointâ€™ reached in Israel-Palestine conflict, urgent action needed on two-State solution
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres has warned that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has reached a breaking point, calling for bold political action to salvage the two-State solution and halt what he described as the systemic dismantling of peace efforts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: LIVE COVERAGE: High-level conference on two-State solution for Israel and Palestine
entry.summary: Welcome to our live coverage of the high-level international conference at UN Headquarters, aimed at advancing practical steps toward achieving a two-State solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict. Mandated by the General Assembly, the three-day meeting features plenaries, working groups and interventions from senior UN officials and Member States. UN News App users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: While Gaza ceasefire remains elusive, UN readies for Conference around Israel-Palestine two-State solution
entry.summary: A world in which a sovereign State of Palestine and Israel co-exist peacefully seems a distant prospect, particularly in light of the 7 October 2023 attacks by Hamas on Israel, and the subsequent Israeli bombardment of Gaza. A high-level UN conference opening on 28 July will, nevertheless, serve as the latest UN-backed attempt to find a way to end the conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Amid starvation in Gaza, Sudan, Guterres slams hunger â€˜as a weapon of warâ€™
entry.summary: As starvation worsens in war-torn Gaza, UN agencies repeated warnings on Monday that Israelâ€™s decision to support a â€œone-week scale-upâ€ of aid is far from enough to reverse deadly malnutrition rates in the enclave.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Trace the backcountry trails of Banff on horseback
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In the side paddock, a team of mules jostles, their heads low, long ears twitching as they snort and stamp impatiently. The beasts â€” horse-donkey hybrids â€” are being loaded up with gear for our expedition into Banff National Park, western Canada, saddle bags of supplies ballooning at their sides. Fuel, food, grain, linen and the inevitable bottle of whisky: itâ€™s a packing list untouched by time.
As the string of mules ambles past in a tethered line, hooves kicking up lazy clouds of dust, it feels like a scene from a Wild West flick, shot in glorious Technicolor against the swaggering backdrop of the Canadian Rockies. But a sidelong glance at the stable yard spins a different yarn, as the present-day wranglers graftâ€¦

entry.title: Why Alabamaâ€™s emerging wine country should be your next road trip
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Given its southerly latitude, it may seem surprising that Alabama is home to a burgeoning wine country. But amid the undulating landscape piercing the stateâ€™s northern half, youâ€™ll find a colourful, characterful wine trail surrounded by some truly beautiful, waterfall-studded scenery. While southern Alabama is as flat as an American pancake, the sylvan foothills of the Appalachian Mountains enter from the northeast of the state and their dense, layered foliage make driving through this corner of â€˜Dixieâ€™ a joy.Â
But donâ€™t expect grand, urbane wineries on the scale of Napa or Sonoma. For the most part, Alabamaâ€™s handful of vineyards are helmed by delightfully small mom-and-pop operations offering warm, avuncular welcâ€¦

entry.title: Look to Austria for wines to try this summer
entry.summary:
Wherever you go in the country, it's hard to overstate Austrians' passion for wine. Known for its aromatic whites, Austria also has outstanding sweet wines, reds and field blends, all best enjoyed in a rural tavern.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
I first came across Austrian wine around 30 years ago in San Francisco, of all places, at a restaurant called The Slanted Door that served Vietnamese food, with which I was equally unfamiliar. I was blown away by a fresh, peppery white called grÃ¼ner veltliner â€” a wine made from a grape of the same name â€” along with how well it suited the dishes weâ€™d ordered.
Since then, itâ€™s become hugely popular. Almost every supermarket has an own-label grÃ¼ner and itâ€™s still my go-to with most Southeast Asiaâ€¦

entry.title: The science behind why Black Sabbathâ€™s music sounded â€˜satanicâ€™
entry.summary:
The idea that two simple notesâ€”not a song, just tonesâ€”could be â€œbannedâ€œ may seem ludicrous. But thatâ€™s the legend behind the crushing opening riff of Black Sabbathâ€™s 1970 debut. With just three ominous notes, guitarist Tony Iommi, alongside the anguished vocals of the late Ozzy Osbourne, unleashed a sound so unsettling it was said to have been forbidden for centuries.â€œThose notes were banned many years ago,â€ Iommi told the BBC in 2014. â€œItâ€™s supposed to have been a satanic thing.â€
While rock legend has never been the most reliable (see: Ozzy and the bat), this one does have a whisper of truth. Black Sabbath recruited what music theorists refer to as the â€˜tritone,â€™ â€”a dissonant interval once avoided by medieval choirs and now known in music lore as the â€œdevilâ€™s interval.â€ Also referredâ€¦

entry.title: Pollution, melting microbes, undamming rivers, risks for elders: 4 key climate issues
entry.summary: In a world increasingly shaped by climate extremes, environmental experts are delivering a blunt warning: four rapidly emerging threats could reshape life for millions unless urgent action is taken.

entry.title: Who were the Neanderthalsâ€”and why did they go extinct?
entry.summary:
This reconstruction of a female Neanderthal was made using ancient DNA evidence. Our ancient ancestors looked similar to modern humans but with more prominent brows and big teeth and eyes. Scientists believe they were also smarter than originally believed. Neanderthals were a hardy species, but these ancient human relatives disappeared 40,000 years ago. Hereâ€™s what scientists know.

  Neanderthals were our closest known relatives and walked the Earth between at least 400,000 and 40,000 years ago. But since their fossilized bones were discovered more than 160 years ago, there are still many questions about what they were like. The bones were uncovered by limestone quarry workers digging in Germanyâ€™s Neander Valley in 1856. At first, they thought theyâ€™d uncovered the â€¦

entry.title: The picturesque Spanish villages that tourists haven't foundâ€”yet
entry.summary:
Slightly up north of Madrid and Barcelona, nestling at the foothills of the Pyrenees, lies the region of Aragon, rich in history and natural beauty. Here, green hills hug the soaring mountains and dense forests open up to flowering meadows. Down in the valleys, ancient castles hide among the olive groves, endless vineyards disappear into the horizon and centuries-old villages bask in the Mediterranean sun all summer long.
Aragonâ€™s historical claim to fame reaches all the way to America. Known as the Kingdom of Aragon in the 11th century, it became a precursor to the modern-day Spain, when King Ferdinand of Aragon married Queen Isabella of Castile in 1469. About two decades later, the royal couple financed Christopher Columbusâ€™s voyage to the New World.Â
In recent years, beautifulâ€¦

entry.title: The UK's nightlife has lost its mojoâ€”can it be saved?
entry.summary:
With tickets to club nights costing up to Â£50 and pints averaging over Â£5, many can't afford to go out any more. Venues are in crisis, with more closures than ever â€” but superclubs, sober parties and new government powers could save the after-dark music scene.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Nights out have been a staple of British life since the early 20th century, when the countryâ€™s first nightclubs opened. But in recent years, the country has seen a surge in venue closures, with a study by the Night Time Industries Association (NTIA) suggesting that there could be no nightclubs by 2030. With a clutch of big openings and a new government taskforce, there are reasons to remain hopeful â€” but are we witnessing the end of nightlife as we know iâ€¦

entry.title: 20 years after Katrina, New Orleanians are redefining 'home'
entry.summary:
Shelton Alexander is one of hundred of thousands of New Orleans residents who survived the devastation of Hurricane Katrina in 2005. After one of the deadliest hurricanes in American history, many New Orleans residents faced a mountain of obstacles to rebuild. These are their stories.
On August 28, 2005, the eve of Hurricane Katrinaâ€™s landfall, Shelton Alexander stood outside his home in St. Bernard Parish, a neighborhood in New Orleans, as a storm warning echoed from a nearby radio. Katrina was gaining strength by the hour.
At that point, the poet and former Marine made sure his mother evacuated. But for himself, staying felt like the only optionâ€”a mix of necessity, responsibility, and quiet defiance in the face of a storm he knew would be unlike anything heâ€™d seen before. â€¦

entry.title: What was it like to live in Old Babylon?
entry.summary:
The city of Babylon, flanking the Euphrates River in Lower Mesopotamia, reached the zenith of its early age during the reign of King Hammurabi (r.1792-1750 B.C.). Under his rule, the capital of the Babylonian empire was consolidated as a cosmopolitan hub, attracting migrants from across the region. The Empire as a whole had been gaining power and prestige during the Old Babylonian Empire (1894â€“1595 B.C.), but Hammurabi went on to take over large swaths of territory in Mesopotamia, conquering far flung cities such as Ur, Eshnunna, Assur, Nineveh, and Tuttul. As Hammurabiâ€™s reach extended, much of the kingdom flourishedâ€”culturally, economically, socially, and in religionâ€” especially in the capital, Babylon.
The thousands of cuneiform texts that survive from this time provide fasciâ€¦

entry.title: How one shipwreck and a cargo of lost gold sparked a U.S. financial panic
entry.summary: When the Central America sank, it became the worst maritime disaster in Americaâ€™s history. The loss of the gold shipment in the hold contributed to a nationwide economic crisis. The S.S. Central America sank off the coast of South Carolina in 1857, taking with it 425 lives and a fortune in gold rush bounty. As the sun slipped below the horizon on the evening of September 8, 1857, a festive atmosphere prevailed in the first-class dining room aboard the S.S. Central America. The side-wheel paddle steamer had left Havana that morning under fair skies and was making its way to New York City on the second and final leg of a voyage that had begun five days earlier in Panama. Aboard were 477 passengers and a crew of 101. Seated at the captainâ€™s table that night was a newlyâ€¦

entry.title: 7 of the best book festivals around the world
entry.summary:
A woman poses for a photo at the Calabash International Literary Festival in Treasure Beach, Jamaica. The family-owned Jakeâ€™s Hotel hosts the annual festival. From Jamaica to Jaipur, these literary festivals celebrate the power of the written word and offer you a chance to hear from celebrated and up-and-coming authorsâ€”as well as fellow bibliophiles.
The ritual of convening around books is a worldwide traditionâ€”from the small fishing village of Treasure Beach in Jamaica to a countryside street in Wales. To pore over a new book in a new setting with like-minded people garners community and inspiration. Add in a gorgeous setting, riveting speakers, and some of the worldâ€™s best restaurants and hotels nearby, and book festivals can serve as a starting point for a greater travel adventuâ€¦

entry.title: Cosmic radiation gave the Fantastic Four superpowers. Here's what would happen in real life.
entry.summary:
When we gaze up at the night sky, we often marvel at the twinkling stars, distant planets, and expansive galaxies. Yet, beyond the visible spectrum lies a more mysterious aspect of the cosmosâ€”cosmic radiation.
These are high energy particles that stream through the universe at nearly the speed of light, according to Dimitra Atri of the Mars Research Group at New York University Abu Dhabi's Center for Astrophysics and Space Science. They originate from events like supernova explosions and solar flares and travel through space, constantly bombarding Earth in all directions and entering its atmosphere.
(How cosmic rays helped find a tunnel in Egypt's Great Pyramid.)
In Marvel Studiosâ€™ The Fantastic Four: First Steps, now playing only in theaters, the Fantastic 4 receive their pâ€¦

entry.title: The women in Carl Jungâ€™s shadow
entry.summary:
For two generations, Emma Jungâ€”the wife of the famous Swiss psychoanalyst Carl Jungâ€”was remembered inside her family mostly as a beloved mother and grandmother. Her original work documenting the deep and rigorous exploration of her own unconscious simply wasnâ€™t discussed.
â€œNo one was any longer aware of what she actually produced,â€ says Thomas Fischer, great-grandson of Carl and Emmaâ€”and the former director of the Foundation of the Works of C.G. Jungâ€”who currently serves as a board member and the editor for the foundation.
Now, 150 years after Carl Jungâ€™s birth, Emma and several of his other female collaborators are finally stepping into the spotlight and being recognized as brilliant thinkers of their own who helped shape some of Jungâ€™s most famous theories, including individuatâ€¦

entry.title: UN urges restraint as Thailand-Cambodia clashes displace thousands; Security Council meets
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General has urged â€œutmost restraintâ€ amid intensifying border clashes between Thailand and Cambodia as the Security Council met behind closed doors on Friday to address the most serious escalation between the two Southeast Asian neighbours in more than a decade.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: Deadly sectarian violence displaces thousands in Sweida; healthcare attacked
entry.summary: As deadly sectarian violence continues to displace hundreds of thousands of civilians in Syriaâ€™s Sweida Governorate, the World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed on Friday that attacks on health facilities had killed two doctors.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: More deaths reported as starvation spreads
entry.summary: The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has again sounded the alarm over the catastrophic and rapidly deteriorating conditions in the Gaza Strip as Israeli military operations continue to cause death, displacement and destruction.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza First Person: â€˜The best of humankind in a place abandoned by humanityâ€™
entry.summary: In the centre of war-torn Gaza, UN staff continue to work despite the â€œunprecedentedâ€ destruction and suffering around them, according to the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) Head of Office.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN warns of escalating human toll in Ukraine amid relentless aerial attacks, mounting aid shortfall
entry.summary: Russian aerial attacks continue to intensify across Ukraine, exacting a rising toll on civilians and infrastructure, senior UN officials told the Security Council on Friday, warning of mounting humanitarian needs amid faltering donor support.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: In hard-hitting human rights address, Guterres calls for urgent action on Gaza, authoritarianism and climate justice
entry.summary: The world is facing a â€œmoral crisisâ€ marked by rising authoritarianism, deepening inequality and a dangerous indifference to human suffering, UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres warns in a powerful address on human rights.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 1.3 million Sudanese return home, offering fragile hope for recovery
entry.summary: With pockets of relative safety emerging in Sudan, over 1.3 million Sudanese people, including one million who were internally displaced and over 300,000 refugees, have returned home, according to UN agencies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Situation in Ukraine
entry.summary: The UN Security Council is meeting on Friday morning to discuss the situation in Ukraine amid mounting concerns over the intensifying hostilities and growing humanitarian needs. Senior UN political affairs and humanitarian officials are expected to brief the Council. Follow our live coverage from UN News, in coordination with UN Meetings Coverage, for updates from the chamber. UN News App users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Women and girls of African descent: Celebrating contributions, recognising challenges
entry.summary: This Friday marks the first observation of the International Day of Women and Girls of African Descent, following a declaration last year by the UN General Assembly.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Forest bathing is the secret to feel-good travel
entry.summary:
Bluebells bloom across a small forest in Shaftesbury, Dorset, United Kingdom. Studies show that forest bathing in woodlands such as this can boost physical and mental health. These five destinations maximize the health benefits of the Japanese art of forest bathing.
Forest bathing emerged in Japan in the 1980s as a physiological and psychological exercise called shinrin-yoku, meaning â€œforest bathingâ€ or â€œtaking in the forest atmosphere.â€ Now this type of walking is a fitness trend and a mindfulness practice for better mental health.
The original purpose was two-fold: to offer an antidote to tech-boom burnout and inspire people to reconnect with and protect the countryâ€™s forests.
The Japanese quickly embraced this form of â€œecotherapy.â€ In the 1990s, researchers began studyâ€¦

entry.title: Why you should visit these 5 European lakes
entry.summary:
These five European lakes are worthy of your attention this summer. From tri-country bike rides around Germanyâ€™s Lake Constance to swims in the shadow of towering mountains in Sloveniaâ€™s Lake Bohinj, Europeâ€™s lakes are so lovely in summer that you wonâ€™t miss the sea for a minute. Packing in history, culture, food, beaches, alley-woven villages and big wilderness, here are five favourites to get you started.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As the summer heat rises along the coast of the Med, turn your gaze instead to Europeâ€™s dazzlingly diverse array of lakes. Beyond swimming, kayaking and standup paddleboarding in crystal-clear waters, thereâ€™s plenty to explore â€” think medieval castles and vineyards, prehistoric pile dwellings and Byzantine mâ€¦

entry.title: Will psychedelics ever live up to their hype?
Are we alone? Earthâ€™s giant new telescope could finally tell us.
How Louis Braille revolutionized a writing system
entry.summary:
Where would we be without writing? From its origins over 5,000 years ago in ancient Mesopotamia, the history of writing echoes the history of humanity. The Greeks and Romans developed unique alphabets, the Chinese evolved complex characters, and today we read novels, newspapers, and social media. A bedrock of human civilization, writing is fundamental for the rule of law and the accumulation of knowledge and culture. Yet it was not until the 19th century that blind people had access to writing.
Between 1824 and 1825, Louis Braille created a system of raised dot letters that could be read with the hands. Initially ignored, his invention would be universally adopted by the 20th century, opening a new world of learning for the visually impaired. In a speech at the Sorbonne on the centennâ€¦

entry.title: This city offers a stunning respite from Veniceâ€™s crowds
entry.summary:
About 40 miles from Veniceâ€™s winding waterways and busy plazas lies Vicenza, an elegant Renaissance jewel. To visit Vicenza is to breathe in the genius of one of historyâ€™s most influential architects, Andrea Palladio.
Though born in nearby Padua, this 16th century architect made his study of classical Greek and Roman architecture central to the design style that later reached throughout Europe and across the Atlanticâ€”a style that inspired Thomas Jefferson to design Monticello after Palladian ideals.
Come for the architecture, but stay to explore a rich tapestry of history and gastronomy. From its museums full of fine art to its stately villas, Vicenza is worth the day trip from Venetoâ€™s more crowded destinations. Â Â
Piazza dei Signori is a beautiful starting point. Itâ€™s heâ€¦

entry.title: Is it possible to take too much melatonin?
entry.summary:
If youâ€™ve ever taken a melatonin supplement as a last-ditch attempt to save your sleep, youâ€™re in good company: Research suggests people in the U.S. have steadily reached for more melatonin over the past couple of decades, and an American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) survey estimates that roughly two-thirds of U.S. adults have used some form of melatonin to help them drift off.Â
The appeal is undeniable: Your brain naturally makes this hormone to regulate your sleep-wake cycle. The synthetic form of melatonin usually found in supplements is a relatively low-risk substance for adults, plus itâ€™s available over the counter. Package this into a trendy bottle brimming with colorful gummies (with plenty of endorsements from â€œwellnessâ€ influencers), and youâ€™re giving the chronically exhaâ€¦

entry.title: Two ex-militia leaders in Central African Republic sentenced for war crimes, crimes against humanity
entry.summary: Two former leaders of the predominantly Christian Anti-Balaka militia in the Central African Republic have been convicted of multiple war crimes and crimes against humanity by the International Criminal Court (ICC).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Thailand-Cambodia border hostilities, humanitarian efforts in Syria and attacks across Ukraine
entry.summary: In a dramatic escalation of a long-standing border dispute, a deadly exchange of fire between Thailand and Cambodia killed at least 11 civilians and a soldier on Thursday, according to news reports. Both states are claiming the other side fired first.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜The UN is here to do the right thingsâ€™: Envoy Colin Stewart bids farewell but keeps the faith
entry.summary: After nearly three decades on the frontlines of UNâ€™s peace operations â€“ from Timor-Lesteâ€™s turbulent independence referendum to Western Saharaâ€™s protracted ceasefire and Cyprusâ€™ frozen conflict â€“ Colin Stewart is leaving the Organization with his faith in it intact.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN forum affirms stronger commitment to achieve sustainable development
entry.summary: The High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF) has concluded at United Nations Headquarters in New York following a week-and-a-half of substantive discussion between Member States, civil society representatives and UN agencies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Famine silently begins to unfoldâ€™ in Gaza, UNRWA chief says
entry.summary: â€œPeople in Gaza are neither dead nor alive, they are walking corpses.â€

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global collaboration grows to address crises in Gaza, Sudan, Afghanistan
entry.summary: Amid growing geopolitical turbulence, the United Nations is deepening its collaboration with the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) to help address some of the worldâ€™s most complex and protracted conflicts, from Gaza and Sudan to Myanmar and Afghanistan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Torture, threats and arbitrary arrests: UN warns of â€˜serious abusesâ€™ against Afghans forced to return
entry.summary: Afghans returning to their country face â€œserious violationsâ€ of their human rights committed by the Taliban de facto authorities, according to a United Nations report published on Thursday amid mass deportation campaigns from Iran and Pakistan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Deep-sea must not turn into â€˜Wild Westâ€™ of rare minerals exploitation, agency head says
entry.summary: Nations are pursuing underwater exploration for highly sought-after rare earth minerals, but the head of the UNâ€™s International Seabed Authority (ISA) said the deep-sea belongs to no single country or corporation as efforts are underway to ensure this rich resource will not become â€œthe Wild Westâ€ of exploitation.

entry.title: Who was Mary Magdalene?
entry.summary:
Mary Magdalene is one of the most recognized figures in the Bible. She has been called a woman possessed by demons, a sex worker, and the wife of Jesus.
Her story has been written and rewritten countless times in the 2,000 years since she was a follower of Jesus of Nazareth, yet so much about Mary Magdalene remains shrouded in mystery. She is sometimes confused with Mary of Bethany, another biblical figure, and thought to have written a Gospel. There are questions about her real name, when and where she was born, and how Mary Magdalene died.
What is true about herâ€”and what archaeological evidence do scholars have about her life and world?
Textual evidence about Mary Magdalene largely comes from the canonical Gospels credited to Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. They identify â€¦

entry.title: Forget about 10,000 steps a dayâ€”science now has a more accurate number
entry.summary:
An explorer walks across sand dunes on Socotra, Yemen, 2018. Getting 10,000 steps in every day can be challenging, and a new study suggests 7,000 steps can reduce the risk of developing common but serious health conditions. Walking more is associated with reduced risk for dementia, diabetes, heart disease, and moreâ€”but a new study says you can get fewer than 10,000 steps a day and still see all those benefits.
If youâ€™ve been told that walking 10,000 steps a day is mandatory for good health, you might be surprised to learn that scientists suspect the figure was created to market pedometers and wasn't based on actual data. The number of steps that stave off numerous chronic conditions is actually much lower, according to a paper published today in Lancet Public Health that reviewed tâ€¦

entry.title: Different dino species traveled togetherâ€”like the movies
entry.summary:
A herd of ceratopsians (Styracosaurus albertensis) accompanied by an ankylosaur (Euplocephalus tutus) walk through an old river channel under the watchful eyes of two tyrannosaurs (Gorgosaurus libratus). A newly discovered trove of fossilized footprints provides what may be the first evidence of prehistoric diversity in dinosaur herds, though not everyone is convinced.
Across the African savanna, zebras and wildebeests travel together in massive herds often peppered with impalas and gazelles. The larger the herd, the safer its members are from predators like lions, hyenas and African wild dogs.
Scientists have wondered whether dinosaurs similarly engaged in mixed-species herding behavior. Childrenâ€™s movies like â€œThe Land Before Timeâ€ series and â€œDinosaurâ€ (2000) often depict mâ€¦

entry.title: Is it a bird? A monkey? No, it's a new prehistoric reptile
entry.summary: Reconstruction and illustration of Mirasaura in itâ€™s natural forested environment Mirasaura grauvogeli had a featherlike crest and a tail like a monkey. â€œIt's been a long time since I've been so blown away by a new fossil discovery.â€ Some 247 million years ago, a bizarre, six-inch-long reptile crept down a branch, its prehensile tail and feet clutching the bark like a monkey, and its narrow, birdlike face scanning its surroundings. On its back, an overlapping fan of stiff structures likely caught the light, vibrant with color. They looked very much like feathers, but were something entirely different as the reptile wasnâ€™t related to birds or dinosaurs, and it existed a hundred million years before the first dinosaur took wing.Â  Researchers have long believed things likeâ€¦

entry.title: How Pew Research Center Uses Its National Public Opinion Reference Survey (NPORS)
entry.summary: In 2020, Pew Research Center launched a new project called the National Public Opinion Reference Survey (NPORS). NPORS is an annual, cross-sectional survey of U.S. adults. Respondents can answer either by paper or online, and they are selected using address-based sampling from the United States Postal Serviceâ€™s computerized delivery sequence file. The post How Pew Research Center Uses Its National Public Opinion Reference Survey (NPORS) appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 10 historicâ€”and sometimes hauntedâ€”hotels in Colorado
entry.summary:
The Brown Palace Hotel was the passion project of Henry Brown, the real estate developer who donated land to create Denver's state capitol building. Ghost stories, swinging saloon doors, and old-world glamourâ€”these hotels offer more character than your average accommodation.
Colorado may be a beloved outdoor recreation destination, but it has more to offer than ski slopes and hiking trails. Once home to miners and cowboys, the Centennial State was a key player not only in the development of the American West but also in establishing Wild West culture. Whether deep in the Rocky Mountains or amid the urban sprawl of Denver, stay in historical hotels to experience this culture for yourself. These properties function as living museums, with antiques, ghosts, and Victorian architecture â€¦

entry.title: Childbirth is still too dangerous. This ancient profession can help.
entry.summary:
A midwife holds a newborn in TzajalchÃ©n, Mexico, 2021. Midwives are making a big comeback, and solving a crisis in maternal health care.
Itâ€™s 5 a.m. at Mother Health International (MHI), a birth center in Northern Uganda affiliated with Yale University, when the call comes in from a local midwife about 12 miles away. A woman in her village has gone into labor. The alert sets a series of gears into motion: a motorcycle driver is immediately dispatched to zip down the mostly unpaved roads to her location, while the nurse midwives at MHI prepare a room for labor and delivery. Within an hour, the laboring mother and her local midwife arrive at MHI where sheâ€™s greeted by nurse midwives who work together to ensure a safe delivery. An ambulance stands ready in case the birth becomes diffâ€¦

entry.title: This one-minute workout could transform your health
entry.summary:
Social media hypes sprinting as a quick fixâ€”but research shows short bursts of high-intensity running can improve VOâ‚‚ max, preserve fast-twitch muscle fibers, and support brain and bone health with minimal time investment. Influencers call sprinting the ultimate fat-burning workout. Experts say itâ€™s more nuancedâ€”but research shows this high-intensity exercise offers surprising benefits for the heart, muscles, and even the brain.
Sprinting has been getting a lot of hype online. But the research backs it up: short, intense bursts of running offer powerful benefitsâ€”from cardiovascular fitness to strength and cognitive function. And you donâ€™t have to do it every day to see results.
Because itâ€™s high-impact, sprinting isnâ€™t right for everyone. But for those without physical limitatâ€¦

entry.title: 8 state parks that deliver the awe without the crowds
entry.summary:
Under the Milky Way Galaxy, a night explorer stands at the entrance to Moon Caves in Nevada's Cathedral Gorge State Park. Less famous but just as unforgettable, these state parks showcase iconic landscapes without the long lines at Americaâ€™s national parks.
As popular national parks grapple withÂ another record-breaking yearÂ of crowds, state-managed public lands offer a less-explored option. While a few parks, like Niagara Falls, with 9 million annual visitors, still contend with crowds, most feel almost deserted. If long lines and packed parking lots have you rethinking your travel plans to some of the busiest national parks, consider one of these eight state park alternatives that deliver the awe without the crowds.Â
With prolific biodiversity within just a dayâ€™s drive of oâ€¦

entry.title: â€˜Corn sweatâ€™â€”and other weird weather phenomenaâ€”explained
entry.summary:
On a hot day, fields of corn transpiring water, also known as "corn sweat", can raise local humidity levels by 30 to 40 percent. The Midwestâ€™s massive corn fields are making the region more humid as it battles a sweltering heatwave.
As the U.S. Midwest swelters under the effects of yet another heatwave, temperatures and humidity in the region are being further fueled by â€œsweatingâ€ corn. If you didnâ€™t have sweaty produce on your 2025 bingo card, youâ€™re not alone; but â€œcorn sweatâ€ is a real phenomenon, well known to meteorologists and farmers alike, that adds moisture to the atmosphere and makes hot conditions even hotter and more unpleasant.
Itâ€™s just one unexpected way in which human activities, from agriculture to deforestation and pollution, can have surprising effects on râ€¦

entry.title: Is it a bird? A monkey? No, it's a new prehistoric reptile
entry.summary: Reconstruction and illustration of Mirasaura in itâ€™s natural forested environment Mirasaura grauvogeli had a featherlike crest and a tail like a monkey. â€œIt's been a long time since I've been so blown away by a new fossil discovery.â€ Some 247 million years ago, a bizarre, six-inch-long reptile crept down a branch, its prehensile tail and feet clutching the bark like a monkey, and its narrow, birdlike face scanning its surroundings. On its back, an overlapping fan of stiff structures likely caught the light, vibrant with color. They looked very much like feathers, but were something entirely different as the reptile wasnâ€™t related to birds or dinosaurs, and it existed a hundred million years before the first dinosaur took wing.Â  Researchers have long believed things likeâ€¦

entry.title: Syria: Second convoy brings critical aid to Sweida
entry.summary: A second convoy from the Syrian Arab Red Crescent (SARC) reached battered Sweida on Wednesday, the UN Office for the Coordinatin of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) reported in its latest update.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Haiti: Violence and displacement driving humanitarian crisis as funding needs go unmet
entry.summary: Escalating gang violence and displacement continue to drive humanitarian needs in Haiti, the UN said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Nigeria: Amid record hunger and surging insecurity, emergency food assistance to stall entirely
entry.summary: At a time of escalating violence and record levels of hunger in Nigeria, critical funding shortfalls are forcing the UN World Food Program (WFP) to suspend all emergency food and nutrition aid for 1.3 million people in the northeast of the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Home is where the heart is â€” and where development begins
entry.summary: When Denis Jobin, a senior evaluation specialist at the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), visited a slum in Kenya in March as part of an ongoing evaluation, the smell was overwhelming.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World Court says countries are legally obligated to curb emissions, protect climate
entry.summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) in the Hague, Netherlands, issued its advisory opinion on the obligations of states in respect of climate change, read out by the President of the Court, Judge Iwasawa Yuji, on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN official reiterates call for Gaza ceasefire as â€˜nightmare of historic proportionsâ€™ unfolds
entry.summary: A senior UN official on Wednesday urged the Security Council to push for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza and the release of all hostages, warning that the war has become â€œa nightmare of historic proportionsâ€ and it is â€œlong past timeâ€ for the fighting to end and for hostages to return home.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Catastrophic birth outcomesâ€™ in Gaza threaten a whole generation, warns UN agency
entry.summary: Pregnant women and newborns in Gaza face â€œcatastrophicâ€ conditions, including a dysfunctional healthcare system, psychological stress and food deprivation the UN reproductive health agency (UNFPA) reported on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Debate on the situation in the Middle East
entry.summary: The Security Council meets today for its quarterly open debate on the situation in the Middle East, with a focus on the worsening crisis in Gaza. UN Assistant Secretary-General Khaled Khiari is expected to brief on the situation in the war-ravaged enclave where food entry and distribution remain severely restricted, malnutrition is rising, and fuel and shelter supplies are critically scarce. UN News, in coordination with UN Meetings Coverage, brings you live updates from todayâ€™s discussions. UN News App users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Who was King Tut, the teen pharaoh who captivated the world?
entry.summary:
King Tut, or Tutankhamun, is one of the most famous rulers who ever lived thanks to the 1922 discovery of the pharaohâ€™s tomb in Egyptâ€™s Valley of the Kings. The find stirred the imaginations of millions who were fascinated by the boy kingâ€™s golden-masked mummy.
But what do we really know about King Tut? Although many details of his reign remain lost to time, historians have spent years trying to piece together the pharaohâ€™s life and legacy. Hereâ€™s what theyâ€™ve learnedâ€”and the biggest questions that remain.
Born during ancient Egyptâ€™s 18th Dynastyâ€”which stretched from 1550 B.C. to 1295 B.C.â€”Tut began his life under a different name: Tutankhaten.
In the years before Tut rose to the throne, Egypt was going through a period of great upheaval. King Amenhotep IV, who is believedâ€¦

entry.title: 8 of the best European national parks to discover this summer
entry.summary:
Mother Nature was at her most adventurous when she shaped mainland Franceâ€™s second-largest national park, the Massif des Ecrins. Fierce summer temperatures can make much of Southern Europe difficult for active, nature-loving breaks in summer. But that still leaves a dazzling array of national parks to explore in the Alps and the north. Here are eight of the best to consider for your next adventure.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Europeâ€™s national parks contain a magnificent array of landscapes; think glaciers, volcanoes, primeval forests, mountain ranges and wild Atlantic coasts. In many cases, summer is the best time to visit them. Here weâ€™ve picked out eight that show off the continentâ€™s diversity as well as its beauty.
These parks arâ€¦
